titleStmt.title: Children Show a Gender Gap in Negotiation

analytic.title: Children Show a Gender Gap in Negotiation

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

p.s: In the United States, there is an unfortunate yet pervasive gender gap in wages: Women tend to make less than men for doing the same work.
One prominent account for why this wage gap exists is that women and men negotiate differently.
However, we currently do not know whether differences in negotiation are a product of extensive experience or are deeply rooted in development.
Here, we brought data from children to bear on this important question.
We gave 240 children between the ages of 4 and 9 years old a chance to negotiate for a bonus with a female or a male evaluator.
Boys asked for the same bonus from a male and a female evaluator.
Older girls, in contrast, asked for a smaller bonus from a male than a female evaluator.
Our findings suggest that a gender gap in negotiation emerges surprisingly early in development, highlighting childhood as a key period for interventions.

One prominent account for the gender gap in pay-the difference in average earnings between women and men-is that women and men negotiate differently (Mazei et al., 2015): Women initiate negotiations less often than men (Azmat & Petrongolo, 2014) and ask for less than men (Gerhart & Rynes, 1991).
This difference is magnified when the evaluators of the negotiation are men (Bowles, Babcock, & Lai, 2007), which, when paired with the overrepresentation of men in upperlevel management (U.S.
Department of Labor, Bureau of Labor Statistics, 2018), can partially account for women tending to negotiate for lower salaries than men.
Although adult research supports the existence of gender differences in negotiation, it cannot reveal their origins.
Learning when these gender differences emerge is imperative for understanding what individual and societal factors lead to these gender differences in adulthood.
We used a developmental approach to fill this gap by examining negotiation in 4-to 9-year-old children.

Building on work with adults, we sought to understand (a) whether girls in this age range would negotiate differently than boys and (b) whether girls, like women, would ask for less from a male than a female evaluator.
By understanding the origins of the gender gap in negotiation, we can shed light on the forces that sustain it in adulthood.
A wide range of gendered behavior emerges early in development and grows more complex between the preschool and elementary years.
By preschool, children identify with a gender (Fagot, Leinbach, & Hagan, 1986), prefer same-sex playmates (La Freniere, Strayer, & Gauthier, 1984), and engage in gendered play (Smith & Inder, 1993).
More complex cultural stereotypes about gender emerge later in development.

In middle childhood, girls begin to show sensitivity to stereotypes associating men with competence, leadership, and high status (Bian, Leslie, & Cimpian, 2017;Liben, Bigler, & Krogh, 2001;Neff, Cooper, & Woodruff, 2007).
These cultural stereotypes deter girls from activities associated with these traits (Bian et al., 2017).

Given the marked developmental changes surrounding gender and gendered behavior observed between preschool and elementary school, it is plausible that gender differences in negotiation may take root during this developmental window.
It is thus important to examine this wide developmental age range to capture the emergence of gender differences in negotiation.
In the current study, boys and girls had the opportunity to ask for a bonus from either a female or a male evaluator.
We focused on two main questions.
First, will girls ask for less than boys?
Second, will girls ask for less from a male than a female evaluator?
We examined a wide developmental window (4-to 9-year-olds) to identify if and when gender differences in negotiation emerge in childhood.
We tested 240 children between the ages of 4 and 9 years old.

To ensure a relatively even distribution across our age range, we recruited children into three predetermined age groups (4-and 5-year-olds: n = 80, M = 5.1 years, SD = 0.5, 40 female; 6-and 7-year-olds: n = 80, M = 7.1 years, SD = 0.6, 40 female; 8-and 9-yearolds: n = 80, M = 8.9 years, SD = 0.6, 40 female).

Twenty-six additional children were excluded because of prior experience with the experimenter (n = 11), refusal to continue participating (n = 8), parental interference (n = 2), lack of motivation for stickers (n = 1), extreme distraction (n = 1), not being able to count (n = 1), and experimenter error (n = 2).
Children were recruited from the Boston, Massachusetts, area and tested in public spaces (n = 238) and a laboratory setting (n = 2).
We did not collect demographic information for participants in public spaces because of constraints from the institutional review board.
Our target sample size was based on similar developmental work (e.g., Bian et al., 2017).
Our goal was to recruit 20 children per gender per evaluator (male or female) per age group.
We ceased data collection for a given cell when we reached our target of 20.

Two of our cells were imbalanced because of a coding error that was caught and corrected, but this meant that we had 21 participants in one cell and 19 in another (see Table S1 in the Supplemental Material available online).
Our task was modeled on real-life negotiations.
In real negotiations, initial requests produce an anchoring effect so that higher initial requests (within reason) result in better negotiation outcomes (Galinsky & Mussweiler, 2001).
These tactics are especially true in settings such as negotiating for a salary bonus, in which evaluators will accept any request less than a certain amount.
Negotiators therefore need to ask for a large amount and slowly reduce their amount requested over time to increase the likelihood that they will find the maximum amount the evaluator will give them.

If negotiators ask for too little on their first request or reduce the amount requested too quickly, the evaluator will accept and keep for themselves the additional amount they would otherwise be willing to give the negotiator.
Our task mirrored these real-world negotiations in that children could ask for as many stickers as they liked in the first phase of negotiations.
Unbeknownst to the children, the evaluator would always accept requests of two stickers or fewer and would always reject requests above that threshold.
If a request was rejected, negotiations would progress to the next phase.
Therefore, our task was designed to measure both participants' initial request and how many trials they persisted in requesting more than two stickers.
Prior to participation, children completed an unrelated lab activity in which we did not examine gender or use stickers as a reward.
These activities consisted of tasks examining social and cognitive development.
Children were not given feedback about how they behaved on these tasks: They were free to make whatever decisions they wanted and to answer questions however they chose.

The majority of these tasks consisted of making decisions about resource distributions, and past work that used the same and similar paradigms as the prior activities, such as the inequity game, has revealed no systematic gender differences in behavior (e.g., Blake & McAuliffe, 2011).
Importantly, these previous activities did not influence our results: Adding the prior activity to our main model did not improve model fitlikelihood-ratio test (LRT), χ²(1) = 6.06, p = .30
(for a replication of our main models with prior study as an additional control, see Table S5 in the Supplemental Material).
To begin the negotiation task, a new experimenter (the evaluator) praised children for completing the prior activity and offered stickers as a bonus prize.
The evaluator was either a man or a woman and did not have any contact with the child prior to the child's participation.
Both evaluators were fully trained, and their delivery of the script was standardized before the first participants were run.

We chose to use only one male and one female evaluator to maximize consistency both within and across evaluators and prioritized these forms of consistency over training a larger number of female and male experimenters, which would have inevitably added more noise to the procedure.
Each child picked his or her favorite type of stickers to negotiate for out of three options to ensure that all children were motivated by the prize.
Then, participants were asked the target question, "How many stickers do you think you should get for completing the game you just played?"
For this first question, children had no information about how many requested stickers the evaluator would accept or reject.
When participants requested two stickers or fewer, the evaluator accepted and the study ended.
When participants asked for more than two stickers, the evaluator said the request was too high and repeated the test question.
Therefore, if participants asked for more than two stickers at this phase, they moved on to the next part of the negotiation task.
At the start of the second phase, the evaluator explained the rules of negotiation to participants.

Participants were told that (Case 1) if they asked for more stickers than the evaluator was able to give them, they would not get any stickers, and (Case 2) if they asked for the same or a smaller number of stickers than the evaluator was able to give them, they would receive the number of stickers they asked for.
These rules were introduced to reflect the risk inherent in negotiations, in which the evaluator has all the power to accept or reject an offer.
Participants were then asked to recall what would happen in Cases 1 and 2, which we refer to as the first and second comprehension check, respectively.
Of the 154 participants who made it to the second phase, 73% passed the first comprehension check, and 82% passed the second comprehension check.
All participants who failed were reminded of the rules again.
Children were then reasked the target question.

If participants asked for more than two stickers after their second request, the evaluator informed the children that there were fewer than three stickers; negotiations ended after children's next request.
Children's persistence was not affected by whether they passed or failed the comprehension checks (see Table S8 in the Supplemental Material).
See Figure 1 for a visualization of the negotiation task.
The design resulted in two dependent variables: size of initial request (observed range = 0-20) and number of trials in which children made above-threshold requests (possible range = 0-2).
Children's responses were recorded live by the primary experimenter and, where possible, later coded from video by an independent video coder.
Video and live coders agreed on 99.13% (227/229) of child responses for the initial request and 100% (229/229) for persistence.
All analyses were conducted using the statistical software R (R Core Team, 2018) and the package MASS (Venables & Ripley, 2002).
Fig. 1.
The negotiation task.
Children completed between one and three trials depending on how many stickers they asked for in each preceding trial.
The question mark represents the target question that evaluators asked each participant: "How many stickers do you think you should get for completing the game you just played?"
If the child ever asked for fewer than three stickers, the study ended.
Any child who passed from Trial 1 to Trial 2 learned the rules of the game: If the child asked for too many stickers, he or she would not receive any.
Any child who passed from Trial 2 to Trial 3 learned that the number of stickers he or she could get was smaller than three.
First, we looked at children's initial requests.
To account for the nonnormal distribution of residuals, we used a negative binomial generalized linear model with age, participant gender, and evaluator gender as our predictors.
There was a significant three-way interaction among age, participant gender, and evaluator gender, β = 0.22, SE = 0.11, odds ratio (OR) = 1.25, 95% confidence interval (CI) = [1.00,
(see Fig. 2; see also Table S2 in the Supplemental Material).
To unpack this interaction, we fitted separate models for boys and girls.
For girls, there was a significant interaction between age and evaluator gender, β = -0.23,
(see Table S2).
Simpleslopes analyses revealed that girls' initial requests decreased with age when the evaluator was male, β = -0.09,
1.00], and increased with age when the evaluator was female, β = 0.14, SE = 0.05, p = .01,
For boys, the age-by-evaluator interaction was not significant, β = -0.01,
(see Table S2).
Simple-slopes analyses revealed that boys' initial requests did not change across our age range with either the male evaluator, β = 0.06, SE = 0.06, p = .29,
1.19], or the female evaluator, β = 0.07, SE = 0.06, p = .24,
See Figure 2 for a visualization of the model outputs reported above (for a visualization of the raw data, see Fig. S2 in the Supplemental Material).

Although we chose to break the model apart by participant gender, note that separating the model by evaluator gender produced the same pattern of results (see Table S6 and Fig. S1 in the Supplemental Material), and a post hoc contrast analysis also showed a similar pattern of results (see Table S7 in the Supplemental Material).

A conservative method for estimating the age at which these gender differences in negotiation emerge is to observe the age at which the 95% CIs around the predicted effects from the model stop overlapping.
Looking at Figure 2, we can see that there is no overlap in CIs for girls by 8 years of age.

Looking only at the 8-and 9-year-old age group, we find that girls requested fewer stickers from a male evaluator (M = 2.75, SD = 1.55) than a female evaluator (M = 4.85, SD = 4.03) and that boys asked for similar amounts from a male evaluator (M = 4.00, SD = 2.51) and a female evaluator (M = 4.75, SD = 4.42).
Additionally, we were interested in children's persistence in our task.
Although we acknowledge that there is a relationship between persistence and children's first ask, we view persistence as additionally informative.
How long a person continues to ask for a greater bonus could also perpetuate gender differences in outcomes from negotiations.
Because persistence was an ordered response term, we used an ordinal logistic regression with age, participant gender, and evaluator gender as our predictors.
Although the three-way interaction was not significant, β = 0.48, SE = 0.29, OR = 1.62, 95% CI = [0.91,

(see Table S4 in the Supplemental Material; for the raw count data of participants' persistence, see Table S3 in the Supplemental Material), the within-gender analyses echoed the initial request results.
For girls, there was a significant interaction between age and evaluator gender, β = -0.57,
(see Table S4).
Simple-slopes analyses revealed that their persistence decreased with age when the evaluator was male, β = -0.33,
0.95], but remained the same with age when the evaluator was female, β = 0.24, SE = 0.15, p = .13,
For boys, the age-by-evaluator interaction was not significant, β = -0.05,
(see Table S4).
Simpleslopes analyses revealed that persistence did not change across the age range when the evaluator was male, β = 0.03, SE = 0.15, p = .82,
These patterns of results suggest that children remain relatively consistent in their persistence across our age range.
Only girls persist less with age when negotiating with a male evaluator.
Our study is the first to show that gender differences in negotiation emerge in childhood.

Older girls in our paradigm differed from boys in how much they were willing to ask for from a male evaluator, showing a striking resemblance to findings in adults (Bowles et al., 2007): Girls are not asking for less from both evaluators but instead are negotiating less only with the male evaluator.
Our findings add negotiation to the list of earlydeveloping gendered behaviors that may lead to and magnify the wage gap in adulthood (Bian et al., 2017;Liben et al., 2001).
For the negotiation literature broadly, our novel paradigm paves the way for exciting new work on children's negotiation behavior.
With respect to the intersection of gender and negotiation, our findings highlight middle childhood as a key period for the development of these behaviors.
There are at least two mechanisms that could account for our pattern of results and that deserve further exploration: status and stereotypes.

With respect to status, it is possible that gender differences in negotiation are driven by individuals who perceive themselves to be of lower status (here, girls) making requests from individuals who they perceive to be of higher status (here, men) and not driven by gender specifically.

With respect to stereotypes, differences in the extent to which girls and boys attribute characteristics such as brilliance (Bian et al., 2017) or competence (Fiske, Cuddy, Glick, & Xu, 2002) to themselves and others could result in girls requesting less than boys in a negotiation context.

Importantly, these are not competing hypotheses but, rather, two avenues that could independently or jointly (Bussey & Bandura, 1999;Liben et al., 2001;Neff et al., 2007) contribute to the gender negotiation gap.

Determining the precise mechanisms that explain our pattern of results is critical for designing interventions to minimize the emergence of gender differences in negotiation starting from elementary school when they first emerge and extending into adulthood.

Although this study is an exciting first step in understanding the origins of the gender gap in negotiation, we must of course be cautious when attributing our effects to evaluator gender specifically because there was only one male and one female evaluator.
It is possible that it was something about these two evaluators that drove these effects besides their gender.
Despite this limitation, we believe our results remain compelling for two reasons.
First, children's gender differences in negotiation emerged with age, suggesting that our male evaluator did not treat boys and girls differently on the whole.

Second, even if it were the case that these differences were specifically due to the individual evaluators rather than their gender, our broader result would stand: Girls, but not boys, show sensitivity to external factors when negotiating, and this sensitivity emerges surprisingly early in development.

It is possible that girls perceived the male evaluator differently with agefor example, as colder (Eckes, 2002;Fiske et al., 2002) or higher status (Liben et al., 2001;Neff et al., 2007)and adjusted their behavior accordingly.
We believe that these data open up exciting avenues for future work that is needed to understand the precise mechanisms driving our findings.
Much attention has been devoted to explaining and closing the gender pay gap, yet these efforts focus almost exclusively on adults (Bowles & Babcock, 2013).
Our findings suggest that these efforts should start earlier in development, as early as elementary school.
Action Editor: Erika E. Forbes Editor: D. Stephen Lindsay drafted the manuscript, and K. McAuliffe provided critical revisions.
Both authors approved the final manuscript for submission.
The author(s) declared that there were no conflicts of interest with respect to the authorship or the publication of this article.
We thank the CIFAR Azrieli Global Scholars Program and The University of Chicago's Earl Franklin Research Fellowship for their support of this research.
All data, analysis code, and materials have been made publicly available via OSF and can be accessed at https:// osf.io/bu6zr/.
The design and analysis plans for this study were not preregistered.
This article has received the badges for Open Data and Open Materials.

badges.
Fig. 2. Model predictions for the number of stickers requested on the first trial as a function of the age of the participant and the sex of the evaluator.
Results for girls and boys are displayed separately.
Shaded areas show 95% confidence intervals.

div.head: Acknowledgments
div.p: We are grateful to the families who participated in this study and the research assistants in the Cooperation Lab for their help with data collection and coding.We especially thank Hogan Gagle for his role as an experimenter.

p.s: Additional supporting information can be found at http:// journals.sagepub.com/doi/suppl/10.1177/0956797620965544
